newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada bonds end weaker, underperform U.S. issues.
newsitem.headline: Canada bonds end weaker, underperform U.S. issues.

text.p: Canadian bonds closed weaker on Tuesday, underperforming their U.S. counterparts amid a weaker Canadian dollar, the pressure of new supply and profit-taking on recent spread narrowing, analysts said.

"The Canadian market just has to consolidate, with Canadian yields venturing where no Canadian yields have ventured before," said Will Sutherland, vice-president of fixed income with Altamira Investment Services Inc.
Canada's 30-year benchmark bond fell C$0.35 to C$106.25 to yield 7.455 percent. The U.S. 30-year benchmark fell 6/32 to yield 6.80 percent.
The spread between the benchmark bonds widened to 66 basis points from 63 basis points at Monday's close.

The spreads between Canadian and U.S. benchmark bonds at the 10- and 30-year portions of the yield curve fell to 11-year lows yesterday. The new lows were reached amid a Canadian dollar rally and strong European buying of Canadian dollar-denominated securities.
Analysts said the recent rally in the currency and bonds are the result of investor recognition of Canada's positive bond market fundamentals such as low inflation and improving government finances.
Analysts said today's underperformance was partly the result of investors taking profits on the recent spread narrowing.
"There's a little bit of profit-taking. We've had a very aggressive run over the last little while, and the currency has eased off," said Mark Chandler, senior economist with Goldman Sachs Canada.
The Canadian dollar closed slightly weaker on Tuesday amid a U.S. currency which was softer from yesterday's close.
In new issue news, Hydro-Quebec this morning set a C$350 million 7.0 percent bond due February 15, 2007.
The issue was priced at C$98.118 with a yield of 7.260 percent for a spread of 47 basis points above the Government of Canada 7.0 percent bond due December, 2006.
In other prices, the 7.0 percent of 2006 fell C$0.24 to C$101.31 to yield 6.817 percent. The U.S. 10-year benchmark fell 5/32 to yield 6.55 percent.
The spread between the two benchmark bonds widened to 27 basis points from 25 basis points.
The three-month cash bill traded at 3.48 percent against the U.S. three-month bill at 5.14 percent.
